MyBaseModel.attachments¶

This class provides the functionality that makes the related-object managers available as attributes on a model class, for fields that have multiple “remote” values and have a GenericRelation defined in their model (rather than having another model pointed at them). In the example “article.publications”, the publications attribute is a ReverseGenericRelatedObjectsDescriptor instance.

class stock.models.MyPosition(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

Stock position on portfolio.

Each position is a stock that user is currently holding. A position is like a tiny accounting book:

position: cost we paid when buying these stocks vol: qty close_position: price we took when selling these stocks

The difference between the buy and sell will be the gain/loss we took buy doing this trade. Also, as long as we are holding it, its value fluctuates along with the market. Thus the source of final gain/loss came from two places:

  1. diff between cost and exit price
  2. fluctuation from the market
exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MyPosition.MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

MyPosition.add(user, price, vol, source='simulation', on_date=None)[source]¶

Utility function to buy or sell.

If vol > 0: buy; < 0: sell. If updated vol == 0, this position will be marked “closed”.

User profile’s cash will be updated: if buy: cash -= price * vol if sell: cash += price * vol

Args:
user:User object. This is also the owner of this position. Buying request

will be compared against user’s quota. :price: buying at price :vol: buying vol :source: used to track live trading. Not used. :on_date: trading date. Not used.

MyPosition.close(user, price, on_date=None)[source]¶

Close position.

Closed price at requested price.

Args:
price:selling price.
MyPosition.cost¶

Cost to establish this position.

cost = position price * holding volume

MyPosition.elapse_in_days¶

Stock’s life in days as of now.

MyPosition.gain¶

Realized gain/loss.

Profit/loss realized by holding this stock till closing.

Unrealized gain/loss is estimated by comparing the last spot price over our initial position price.

class stock.models.MySimulationCondition(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

Simulation condition model.

A simulation condition represents a particular set of parameters that form the context of a simulation run, eg. which data set to use, what date period to use, how many capital to begin with, and how much we want to spend per trade.

Fields:
strategy:Defines which strategy one would use for a simulation run. S1 strategy calls for an index value precalculated based on certain algorithm and trade based; S2 is a buy low sell high strategy that will monitor a stock’s open/close/spot to determine when to buy and when to sell.
buy_cutoff:If a stock has dropped over buy_cutoff percentage, one buys this stock. This value has different meanings in different strategies. In S1, this is the cutoff band that has grouped stocked based on a pre-computed index value; in S2, this is daily drop %.
sell_cutoff:As the counterpart to the buy_cutoff, sell_cutoff defines a percentage that one would close a position. In S1 this is the band when a stock falls outof a artificial band determined by a pre-computed index value; in S2 this is the percentage relative to the initial price at buying.
DATA_CHOICES = ((1, 'S&P500'), (2, 'CI00*'), (3, 'WIND 8821*'), (4, 'China stock'), (5, 'WIND 2nd-tier sector'))¶
DATA_SORT_CHOICES = ((0, 'ascending'), (1, 'descending'))¶

class stock.models.MySimulationResult(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

Simulation result model.

This is a complex model because it will save the raw data from a simulation run so we can replay the entire simulation step by step.

exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception MySimulationResult.MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

MySimulationResult.asset¶

A placeholder class that provides a way to set the attribute on the model.

MySimulationResult.asset_cumulative_return¶

Measures daily asset’s return over T0’s.

This indes shows how assets swings comparing to simulation’s T0. This can be viewed as an overall performance indicator over time.

MySimulationResult.asset_cumulative_return_mean¶

Average gain.

Numeric mean of gains. This indicates the likely gain one can achieve by applying this strategy.

MySimulationResult.asset_cumulative_return_std¶

Standard deviation of cumulative gains.

This measures the risk of applied strategy using cumulative gain data.

MySimulationResult.asset_daily_return¶

User asset’s daily change in pcnt.

This index shows how a user’s asset fluctuates from day to day during simulation period.

MySimulationResult.asset_end_return¶

Last’s day’s cumulative return.

MySimulationResult.asset_max_return¶

Best return % during simulation period.

This indicator shows the maximum potential gain from applied strategy.

MySimulationResult.asset_min_return¶

Worst return rate during simulation period.

This shows the worst moment this strategy can yield.

MySimulationResult.cash¶

A placeholder class that provides a way to set the attribute on the model.

MySimulationResult.condition¶
MySimulationResult.equity¶

A placeholder class that provides a way to set the attribute on the model.

MySimulationResult.equity_portfolio_gain_pcnt¶

Equity gains from holding.

This tracks equity gains from holding a perticular stock, not from trading it. It indicates how well equities were performing. This is completely determined by how well we picked stock, thus is a good indicator of applied strategy.

MySimulationResult.equity_portfolio_life_in_days¶

Equity life in days.

We want to measure how long we usually hold a position. One strategy is to dictate how long we can hold a position.

MySimulationResult.equity_trade_gain_pcnt¶

Equity gains from trading.

This tracks gains from closing stocks based on applied strategy. This is influenced by both stock picking strategy and trading strategy. So it measures the effect of both.

MySimulationResult.num_of_buys¶

Total number of buys.

This is computed from individual buys.

MySimulationResult.num_of_sells¶

Total number of sells.

This is computed from individual sells.

MySimulationResult.objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>¶

A placeholder class that provides a way to set the attribute on the model.

A placeholder class that provides a way to set the attribute on the model.

A placeholder class that provides a way to set the attribute on the model.

MySimulationResult.transaction¶

A placeholder class that provides a way to set the attribute on the model.

class stock.models.MyStock(id, company_name, symbol, sector, is_sp500, is_china_stock, prev_close, prev_open, prev_high, prev_low, prev_vol, day_open, pe, bid, ask, vol, floating_share, day_high, day_low, last, last_update_time, is_in_play, prev_change, day_change, spread, vol_over_float, week_adjusted_close, month_adjusted_close, fib_weekly_adjusted_close, fib_daily_adjusted_close, fib_weekly_score, fib_daily_score)[source]¶

MyStock.fib_daily_score_pcnt¶

Fibonacci daily score.

MyStock.fib_weekly_score_pcnt¶

Fibonacci weekly score in %.

Score is calculated by sampling in time based on Fib values as time intervals. The score is computed offline so it is historically correct.

MyStock.month_change¶

Closing price over the openning price 1-month ago.

MyStock.myposition_set¶
MyStock.mysector_set¶
MyStock.mystockhistorical_set¶
MyStock.objects = <stock.models.MyStockCustomManager object>¶
MyStock.oneday_change¶

Midday change percentage

Midday change is computed as:
(last polled bid price/today’s openning price) in %
MyStock.trend_is_consistent_gain¶

Stock is growing consistently.

A stock is considered gaining consistent when: 1. it gained today 2. it gained since yesterday’s opening 3. it gained in this week 4. it gained in this month

Taking four segments forces a stronger check against its price trend. There isn’t a particular theory behind such check. But IMHO, a consistend gain is an indicator of a rare gaining period.

MyStock.trend_is_consistent_loss¶

Reverse of consistent_gain. See above.

MyStock.twoday_change¶

Current bid over yesterday’s openning price in percentage.

MyStock.week_change¶

Weekly closing price over the same week’s openning price.

Data is saved in week_adjusted_close as (open,close) delimited by comma. This format is copied by Yahoo!Finance.

stock.serialize_json module¶

JSON serialization routines for python data types.

Retains type information for basic python datatypes that do not have a direct mapping to JSON without abusing JSON too much. Format is similar to the one used by jsonpickle, though not guaranteed to be compatible.

Currently handles dictionaries with non-string-keys, tuples, sets, numpy arrays, namedtuples, and OrderedDicts.

stock.simulations module¶

class stock.simulations.MySimulation(user, simulation)[source]¶

Bases: object

Abstract model.

This model defines a common simulation run framework. All strategies will use the same structure in 3 steps:

# get raw data # simulate # record transactions

The difference of strategies lie in the actual implementation of “buy” and “sell”. Therefore, new simulation simply inherit this class and define two functions: “buy” and “sell”.

buy(**kargs)[source]¶

Children class should override this function to define its own buy actions.

run()[source]¶
sell(**kargs)[source]¶

Children class should override this function to define its own sell actions.

setup()[source]¶

Setup date set.

Return:
boolean:False if there is not enough historical data for this simulation. Most likely this is caused when date ranges requested is out of sync with background data feeder. True otherwise.
class stock.simulations.MySimulationAlpha(user, simulation)[source]¶

Bases: stock.simulations.MySimulation

Trading strategy:

  1. Stocks are ranked by a pre-calculated index value
  2. Buy stocks whose rank is above the buy_cutoff band, eg. if buy_cutoff = 0.25 and total samples = 20, buy if rank <= 0.25*20=5
  3. Sell stocks when it falls out the sell_cutoff band, eg. if sell_cutoff = 0.75 and total samples = 20, sell if rank >= (1-0.75)*20 = 5

We simulate trades based on this strategy, then monitor the porfolio value (equity+cash).

buy(on_date, symbols)[source]¶
sell(on_date, symbols)[source]¶
class stock.simulations.MySimulationJK(user, simulation)[source]¶

Bases: stock.simulations.MySimulation

Trading strategy:

  1. Stocks are ranked by one-day change percentage. If pcnt < 0, price has dropped. The bigger the drop, the higher the rank.
  2. Buy stocks whose rank is above the buy_cutoff band, eg. if cutoff = 0.25 and total samples = 20, buy if rank <= 0.25*20=5
  3. Sell if stock’s price has recovered more than sell_cutoff, eg. if cutoff = 0.25 and position @ 100, selll if new price >= 100*(1+0.25)
buy(on_date, symbols)[source]¶
sell(on_date, symbols)[source]¶

Simulation run.

Arguments:
is_update:True if we are to remove existing simulation results and run simulation from scratch; False will exit if there are existing results already so we don’t run the same simulation twice.
class stock.tasks.MyStockBacktesting_1[source]¶
parser(symbol)[source]¶
class stock.tasks.MyStockCCI[source]¶

Bases: stock.tasks.MyStockStrategyValue

CCI Indicator.

MA = Average(Price,Len); value1=0; for i=0 to Len-1

value1+ = |Price[i]-MA|;

value1=value1/Len; CCI = (Price-MA)/(0.015*value1);

compute_value(t0, window)[source]¶
class stock.tasks.MyStockDailyReturn[source]¶

Bases: stock.tasks.MyStockStrategyValue

Daily return value.

Compute historical oneday_change = (today’s close - prev’s close)/prev’s close *100

compute_value(t0, window)[source]¶
class stock.tasks.MyStockDecyclerOscillator[source]¶

Bases: stock.tasks.MyStockStrategyValue

Decycler Oscillator (Price, HPPeriod, K); HPPeriod=10, K=1

Alpha1= (Cos(0.707*360/HPPeriod) + Sin(0.707*360/HPPeriod)-1)/Cos(0.707*360/HPPeriod) HP = (1-Alpha1/2) * (1-alpha1/2)*(Price-2*Price[1]+Price[2]) +

2*(1-Alpha1)*HP[1] -(1-Alpha1)*(1-alpha1)*HP[2];

Decycle = Price-HP; Alpha2 = (Cos(0.707*360/(0.5*HPPeriod)) + Sin(0.707*360/(0.5*HPPeriod))-1)/Cos(0.707*360/(0.5*HPPeriod)) DecycleOsc = (1-Alpha2/2) * (1-alpha2/2)*(Decycle-2*Decycle[1]+Decycle[2]) +

2*(1-Alpha2)*DecycleOsc[1] -(1-Alpha2)*(1-alpha2)*DecycleOsc[2];

Indicator= 100*K*DecycleOsc/Price;

compute_value(t0, window)[source]¶

class stock.tasks.MyStockRelativeMovingAvg[source]¶

Bases: stock.tasks.MyStockStrategyValue

Relative Position Indicator.

Using moving Average= (Price - Average(Price,Len))/StdDev(Price,Len). Len is 40 by default.

class stock.tasks.MyStockSI[source]¶

Bases: stock.tasks.MyStockStrategyValue

SI indicator. K = max( |H - C[1]|, |L-C[1]|); R = the largest of :

if H-C[1], then |H-C[1]|-0.5|L-C[1]|+0.25|C[1]-O[1]| if L-C[1], then |L-C[1]|-0.5|H-C[1]|+0.25|C[1]-O[1]| if H-L, then H-L+0.25|C[1]-O[1]|

SI Indicator = 50*(C-C[1] + 0.5*(C-O) + 0.25*(C[1]-O[1])*K/R

compute_value(t0, window)[source]¶
class stock.tasks.MyStockStrategyValue[source]¶

Bases: object

Abstract model that defines a “run” method that can overriden by children class to define their own compute_value method, which computes the so called index value per strategy.

occurrences(haystack, needle)[source]¶

Count occurences of a substring within a string.

This is a helper function to count the number of occurance of a pattern (substring) within a string.

Args:
haystack:a string or list. The long string we are to search for a pattern.
needle:a string or list. the pattern we are searching.
Returns:
int:number of occurance

stock.views.class_view_decorator(function_decorator)[source]¶

Convert a function based decorator into a class based decorator usable on class based Views.

Can’t subclass the View as it breaks inheritance (super in particular), so we monkey-patch instead.
